app.cards.game

Class Flush

  • java.lang.Object
    • app.cards.game.Flush
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    HandValue, java.lang.Comparable<Flush>

    public class Flush
extends java.lang.Object
implements HandValue, java.lang.Comparable<Flush>

    This class encapsulate five Cards that make a flush.

    A Flush instance is created via makeBestFlush(Set) from a Set of Cards.

    • Method Detail

      • makeBestFlush

        public static Flush makeBestFlush(java.util.Set<Card> suitedCards)
        Creates the best possible Flush from the provided Set of Cards
        Parameters:
        suitedCards - Set of cards of the same suit, possibly more than 5
        Returns:
        Sorted list of the five cards within suitedCards that make the best flush. Straight flushes are not considered; instead, they are classified as Straights and will be detected by calling Straight.makeBestStraight(CardSequence).

      • getCards

        public java.util.Collection<Card> getCards()
        Description copied from interface: HandValue
        A Collection of all Cards of this HandValue
        Specified by:
        getCards in interface HandValue
        Returns:
        All Cards whose combination constitutes this specific HandValue

      • getNthHighestCard

        public Card getNthHighestCard(int n)
        The n-th highest Card of the Flush
        Parameters:
        n - position of the desired card, from 1 (best card) to 5 (worst card)
        Returns:
        The n-th best Card as determined by the RankBeforeSuitComparator

      • getHighestCard

        public Card getHighestCard()
        The best Card of the Flush (shortcut for getNthHighestCard(1))
        Returns:
        The best Card as determined by the RankBeforeSuitComparator

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Flush other)

        Compares this Flush to another.

        A flush f1 is better than a flush f2 if its highest card is better. If the highest cards of both flushes are equal, the flush with the better second-highest card wins and so on.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Flush>
        Returns:
        A negative number if other is better than this Flush, a positive number if this Flush is better than other, 0 if they're equal.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        A human-readable representation of this Flush as the List of its cards enclosed in curly braces
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
